Hi @brettskipp4311 

An associate level exam is what is intended to validate core skills in production planning & manufacturing in private cloud context.

It is useful to have the credentials especially early in your SAP career, but you can unlock the full value when you combine it with real world implementation experience.

SAP Certified Associate - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, Production Planning and Manufacturing

For question 2, my suggestion is to combine SAP‚Äôs official learning journey with some practice exams and hands-on practice.

Regarding your third question, in my opinion Advanced Planning and Master Data/Production Orders section often carry the heavier weights. Also, scenario-based or integration question often prove more difficult because they require you to link your knowledge across modules.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: OAuth 2.0 Client Type in S4HANA Cloud Public
entry.content:
Hello @KhaingZinTun 

In S/4HANA Public Cloud, the screen is set to Public Client with Authorisation Code (PKCE), and switching to Client Credentials is not possible. SAP‚Äôs official documentation on PKCE public clients for inbound OAuth in Communication Systems/Arrangements confirms these fixed settings, with no option to change the grant type to Client Credentials.SAP Help Portal-Enabling Public OAuth Clients (PKCE) for Inbound Communication Scenarios

For server-to-server communication without user interaction, SAP‚Äôs recommended approach is to call S/4HANA Cloud through SAP BTP Destinations using OAuth2SAMLBearerAssertion (or Basic/Client Certificate where applicable), rather than using Client Credentials within S/4HANA‚Äôs inbound user.SAP Community-OAuth2SAMLBearerAssertion Flow with the SAP BTP Destination Service. S/4HANA Cloud.

Let me know if you need further information

With best regards

Chuma

entry.title: Intelligent Supply Chains in Action: Fujitsu‚Äôs Agentic AI Approach to Global Trade Challenges
entry.content:
Introduction

Across industries, supply chain disruptions have become the new normal. Global manufacturers are navigating a complex web of challenges, including shifting trade policies, volatile energy prices, climate-driven events, and the growing demand for sustainable operations. The systems and strategies that once brought stability now struggle to keep up with this constant change.

According to a 2024 report by Maersk, 76% of respondents reported experiencing supply chain disruptions, and a startling 58% of them reported that the costs exceeded their predictions. From sudden tariff changes that reshape sourcing decisions to unexpected raw material shortages or port closures, disruptions no longer come one at a time as they overlap, compound, and evolve faster than traditional planning tools can respond.

In this environment, organisations need more than data visibility. They need decision intelligence systems that can sense change, learn continuously, and act responsibly in real time. This cannot be achieved in isolation, and an ecosystem or network play is a must. This is also where the latest innovations in Artificial Intelligence, like Agentic AI, can help redefine supply chain resilience.

The role of Agentic AI in Supply Chain Resilience

Agentic AI has the potential to power the next evolution of intelligent supply chain management. Instead of waiting for analysts or planners to interpret data, AI agents can continuously monitor supply, logistics, and market signals and then autonomously simulate and recommend the best response.

A few scenarios include:

  • Sudden geopolitical tensions? AI agents instantly recalculate costs, identify alternate suppliers, and propose optimised procurement mixes.
  • An energy-price surge? AI agents can suggest shifting production to lower-cost facilities or off-peak hours to protect margins and emissions goals.

SAP and its partner ecosystem are harnessing the power of Agentic AI to bring the vision of an intelligent supply chain to life. As a strategic SAP partner, Fujitsu is at the forefront of this innovation - creating next-generation solutions that enhance visibility, resilience, and responsiveness across global value networks.

Among the many factors disrupting supply chains today, cross-border tariffs remain one of the most complex and persistent challenges. In this article, we explore how Fujitsu‚Äôs Agentic AI-driven offerings are designed to help businesses anticipate, adapt to, and overcome these disruptions - enabling a smarter, more connected, and future-ready supply chain.

Building a Resilient Supply Chain to respond to Trade disruptions

In recent months, global trade dynamics have become increasingly unpredictable. The rules that once made it easy for goods to flow across borders - like free trade agreements - are now being challenged by new tariffs, shifting political alliances, and unexpected disruptions across the trade lanes. In a recent study published by BCG in 2025, it is estimated that at least 20% to 30% of EBIT margins for companies across all manufacturing sectors are at risk from higher tariffs!

Real-World Example: How Agentic AI Transformed a Global Electronics Manufacturer

A leading global electronics manufacturer in Asia faced significant challenges stemming from supply chain uncertainties, siloed enterprise systems and fragmented data. Their complex IT landscape made it difficult to access and interpret critical information across departments, slowing down decision-making during high-stakes disruptions.

Traditional point-to-point data integration approaches would have taken years to unify these disparate systems. Instead, the company sought a transformative solution - one that could consolidate enterprise data, enrich it with industry and business context, and dramatically accelerate decision cycles.

Agentic AI proved pivotal in transforming the company‚Äôs response to disruptions.

During disruptions such as trade tariffs or natural disasters like earthquakes, the manufacturer needed to rapidly assess the impact across their supply chain. This required synthesising internal enterprise data with external sources such as demographic trends, trade data, and harmonised system (HS) codes to simulate scenarios and take informed action.

As part of a broader digital transformation initiative, the company explored how Agentic AI could address supply chain shortages. By deploying intelligent agents across multiple systems - procurement, sales, inventory, and orchestration - they enabled real-time data access and contextual decision-making. These agents were trained to perform specialised tasks and provide actionable recommendations to business users.

For example, in the case of a raw material shortage, agents could evaluate multiple alternatives:

  • Sourcing from an alternative supplier,
  • Adjusting production schedules based on material availability, or
  • Engaging with customers to reschedule orders while maintaining service levels.

Each scenario required granular simulation across millions of SKUs, factoring in product, customer, and supplier contexts. The orchestrator agent played a pivotal role by assessing each option through the lens of cost, priority, and service level, ultimately recommending the most optimal path forward.

This innovative use of Agentic AI not only enhanced agility and collaboration across the enterprise but also earned a global recognition. The World Economic Forum‚Äôs AI Governance Alliance acknowledged this solution as one of 18 advanced AI applications transforming business worldwide.

Turning Data into Decisions

Expanding data visibility across enterprise, market, and regulatory sources enhances predictive accuracy and resilience.

Some other examples of how companies can use data and smart technologies to solve supply chain challenges encountered in tariff change scenarios are as follows:

  • Profit and Cost Analysis: By mapping out where costs are rising due to tariffs, companies can decide whether to pass those costs on to customers, absorb them, or find cheaper alternatives.
  • Pricing Simulations: Businesses can test how different prices will affect demand and profits in different tariff scenarios, helping them find the best balance between staying competitive and making money.
  • Operational Changes: If a key supplier is hit by a new tariff, companies can quickly see what other options are available, compare costs and quality, and make a switch if needed.

Fujitsu‚Äôs Multi-AI Orchestration Platform

Fujitsu has developed a Multi-AI agent orchestration platform for use cases such as Profit Margin & Cost Analysis that can leverage data stored in both SAP and non-SAP systems to present specific scenarios that can impact a customer‚Äôs supply chain. Using the simulation capabilities of this offering, multiple scenarios can be developed and compared, and the right strategy can be devised. The agentic AI platform leverages the data and helps to implement the decisions back into SAP applications like SAP S/4HANA SAP Integrated Business Planning and SAP Digital Manufacturing to effectuate the optimal plan chosen earlier. In the future, these agents could be extended to support SAP Business Network Supply Chain Collaboration and Supply Chain Orchestration as well.

These offerings are also complementary to the AI innovations delivered by SAP with the Business Suite e.g. seamless access with Joule, enhanced collaboration and decision making with SCM agents, etc.

Preparing for an AI-Enabled Future

Introducing technological capabilities isn‚Äôt enough. Companies also need to change the way they work with AI. This includes:

  • Cultivating an ‚ÄúAI-first‚Äù mindset: AI projects executed with a traditional mindset rarely deliver transformative outcomes. A transformational mindset is required to transform supply chains with AI. A few key aspects are as follows:
    • Myths like ‚ÄúAI will completely replace humans‚Äù are making way to ‚ÄúAI agents will work alongside humans‚Äù. But accepting this at an individual level requires humans to trust AI.
    • Especially within the supply chain, one cannot afford to have unreliable supply chain plans or manufacturing schedules. Balancing the level of AI autonomy with human empowerment is key to gaining this trust.
    • An AI-first and transformational mindset is required in transforming supply chains with AI
  • AI upskilling: Technologies such as Generative AI are being widely used by people to simplify their personal tasks. However, when it comes to corporate use of such tools, there are several nuances that we need to be aware of, like trusted tools, enterprise context and security concerns. These also apply specifically to the use of AI in supply chains
  • Improve Network relationships: A supply chain network includes partners like component suppliers, logistics partners etc. These partners are important to ensure optimal running of the supply chain in normal times and become critical during disruptions. Trusted data sharing, clear communication channels, and robust digital capabilities are critical to sustaining a resilient partner ecosystem

Conclusion

Agentic AI is redefining how organisations anticipate, adapt, and act amid global supply chain volatility. Fujitsu and SAP‚Äôs joint innovation demonstrates that the future of supply chain resilience lies not just in data, but in intelligent, autonomous collaboration.

Learn More

If you‚Äôd like to see how such technology can be turned into a solution in action or to learn more, consider attending the Fujitsu ActivateNow event in Singapore.

What did you think about this post? Please leave your feedback, thoughts, and suggestions in a comment below.

Also, please follow the co-authors: @RajeshMohan, @pavneetbedi and @naimul_islam42  so that you do not miss any future posts.

You may also be interested in the following blogs:

  • Driving Supply Chain Excellence with Business AI
  • Driving Resilience Through Intelligent Supply Chain Orchestration
  • Tariffs in Supply Chain Planning

entry.title: Set up depreciation areas in Asset Accounting in S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition with UPA
entry.content:
Purpose

In Universal Parallel Accounting (UPA), Asset Accounting (AA) has almost everything redesigned, from database tables to the user interfaces, from configurations, master data to depreciation calculation,  and from overall architecture to the technical implementation. 

The way to set up ledgers and depreciation areas is a part of those big changes. This article discusses how to set it up in Asset Accounting in S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition with UPA. It also describes a couple of common mistakes that can be easily made by users who are coming from the non-UPA.

Depreciation Areas in a Non-UPA System

Before UPA was introduced, it was a complex task to set up the depreciation areas in AA. Quite often, in a non-UPA system, you will see the following setup.

However, from an accountant point of view, this setup is confusing. For example, what kind of accounting principles can be called 'TAX' accounting principle? Which country is using an accounting principle called 'LOCAL'?

Ledgers and Accounting Principles in UPA

Concept

Accounting principles are rules to govern how companies record and report their financial data. The most famous accounting principles is International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) issued by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB). In addition, there are local accounting principles, for example, the United States Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (US GAAP) or German Commercial Code (Handelsgesetzbuch, HGB).

Ledgers build the basis for reporting and financial statements in Accounting by storing related transaction data and journal entries. For this reason, all posting-relevant configuration settings for a company code, such as the accounting principles, currency settings, fiscal year variants (FYVs), and posting periods, must be linked to a specific ledger. 

Regardless UPA or non-UPA, it is always recommended to assign the leading ledger to the accounting principle of the corparate group, while in parallel, the non-leading ledgers for the local accounting principles.

In practice, there is a commonly made mistake: to create an accounting principle called 'LOCA' and assign ledgers to it. Perhaps the users may want to clone what they did in the past (non-UPA) into the UPA system. But this is wrong. You must not use a generic local accounting principle for all country and assign it to the local ledger. Always create a dedicated accounting principle per country. Below is an example to show you how to do it in UPA.

Set Up of Ledgers and Accounting Principles

The setup of ledger and accounting principle is done in the t-code FINSC_LEDGER. In order to make it easier to explain the concept, we start the example in an Excel file, with a flat the structure as shown in the screenshot below, then followed by the screenshots made in the system.

This example follows the SAP recommendation to manage the corporate valuation (e.g. IFRS) in the leading ledger 0L. In t-code FINSC_LEDGER, once you enter 'IFRS' at the ledger 0L, you will have it inheritted into all company codes that are assigned to 0L automatically. 

The ledger 2L is used for local accounting principles. So, leave 'Accounting Principle' as blank on ledger 2L. In all company codes that are assigned to 2L, enter the right accounting principles for those individual company codes.

In UPA, Asset Accounting  (AA) has a in-depth integration with General Ledger (G/L) Accounting. All currency types are set up in G/L and managed by G/L. You don't have to create a separate depreciation area for each currency type. 

With this fundamental setup in G/L, you can step into AA configurations. 

Depreciation Areas and Valuation Views in UPA

Concept

Depreciation areas in AA play the same role as ledgers do in G/L, but with a more fine-granular structure than a ledger.

'Valuation View' does not exist in AA with non-UPA. However, in UPA, this is one of the most important concepts. It is designed to map valuations in accordance with different valuation rules, for example, according to local commercial or tax laws, or according to international accounting principles. 

Valuation views can be pre-delivered (To learn more about it, see the Best Practice Content section under Miscellaneous Topics at the end of this article). But if you want to define your own valuation views, it is always recommended to define a dedicated valuation view per country. Do not resue them in a generic way.

Setup of Valuation Views

T-code FAACFG contains all configurations of AA. This artical mainly focuses on the configuration under the node 'Basic Settings for Valuation'.

It is recommended to define exact one valuation view for the corporate accounting principle, e.g. 0IFRS_0032 for IFRS below.

For each local accounting principle, create a set of valuation views for it. For example, 0DE_0001 and 0DE_0015 below for German accounting principle. The assignment is done in the configuration node 'Assign Valuation View to Accounting Principle'.  The property 'Posting in G/L', a.k.a. Posting Type, plays an important role in the posting. See the next chapter for more details.

Valuation views have properties to decide the rules for depreciation calculation and asset transactions. For example, both 0DE_0001 and 0DE_0015 have:

  • Net Book Value (NBV) set to '*'.
    This means negative NBV is allowed in the depreciation areas assigned to these valuation views.
  • Revaluation set to '*'.
    That means corresponding depreciation areas support revaluation. Those depreciation areas and the corresponding ledgers are selectable in Post Asset Revaluation app (or t-code ABAWL). ‚û°Ô∏è In another word, if you cannot select any ledger or deprecation area there, please check out the settings here in the corresponding valuation views. This is a commonly made mistake as well.

Setup of Depreciation Areas

Now it is the time to create depreciation areas for your company codes. Each depreciation area must be assigned to a valuation view, and thus linked to the corresponding ledger.

In UPA, it is a lot more easier to set up depreciation areas, once you have configured valuation views right. You don't have to create a separate depreciation area for every currency type. Since currency types are configured in G/L at ledger level, every depreciation area manages all currency types that are defined in the corresponding ledger. This is a significant improvement in UPA.

‚ö†Ô∏èImportant to know:

  • Since AA has a deep integration with G/L, it is not allowed to have a ledger defined in G/L but not used in AA. For example, if 2L is not used in AA, system will report an error message.
  • The property 'Posting in G/L' of valuation view 0DE_0001 is '1 - Area Posts in Real Time'. Therefore, for the depreciation area assigned to this valuation view (depreciation area 32), system save line items with the corresponding ledger, i.e. 2L, in this example.
  • The property 'Posting in G/L' of valuation view 0DE_0015 is '0 - Area Does Not Post'. Thus, line-items for the depreciation area 15 are saved with the technical ledger of 2L in ACDOCA. (You can find the ID of the techincal ledger in the database table FINS_TECH_LEDGER)

‚ö†Ô∏èSomething more about derived areas, a.k.a. virtual area in non-UPA.

  • In non-UPA, a virtual area, which is called 'Derived Area' in UPA now, can calculate values from areas belonging to different ledgers. This is not allowed anymore in UPA, where a derived area can only be built on depreciation areas from the same ledger.
  • In non-UPA, nothing from a virtual area is stored into database. Everything is calculated on-the-fly. However, in UPA, to make them accessible in Fiori analytics reports, AA designs it differently. If a derived area is included in an asset:
    1. This derived area is also stored in the asset master record.
    2. If 'Posting in G/L' in the corresponding valuation view is '0 - Area Does Not Post', line-items for this derived area are stored in the corresponding technical ledger in ACDOCA, . This is similar to what has been described in the last bullet-point of 'Important to know''.
    3. If 'Posting in G/L' is '4', line-items for this derived area are posted to the normal ledger. For example, in a France company code, ledger 2L is configured for local GAAP 'FRAP'. The line items for derived area 93 are posted to the ledger 2L, but not the corresponding technical ledger of 2L.

Is Everything Correct?

You are almost there. But how to know if everything has been set up correctly? AA has provided a nice tool for this purpose. That is the one being highlighted below.

It provides a lot of checks. For the configurations described in this article, just turn on the first option 'Basic Settings for Valuation'. This tool will tell you if there is still anything missing or wrong in the configuration.

Miscellaneous Topics

Group Valuation Ledger

To set up a dedicated ledger for group valuation in addition, create a ledger in FINSC_LEDGER (e.g. 4G), and choose '1 Group Valuation'  for it, as shown below.

Next, in the company codes that are assigned to 4G, enter the currency types that are defined for group valuation, e.g. 11, 31, etc. You should have defined these currency types in the node 'Currency Type' of FINSC_LEDGER, beforehand.

Best Practice Content

All the discussions in this article start with valuation views. How should those valuation views be created properly? Referring to the best practice content is the best way.

All configuration tables in AA have their best practice (default) content delivered by SAP in each release. You can choose which client should be used for those default content. After activating the best practice content, you will see all those default configuration in the client you have provided, including everything being mentioned in this article.

This is a separate topic and cannot be covered in this article. Please refer to this page for more details.

Summary

This article discusses about how to set up accounting principles, ledgers and depreciation areas in UPA, with basic examples.

It is also worth mentioning that AA groups depreciation keys by accounting principles. So corporate roll-out becomes easier than before. You may check out the relevant configuration in the node: FAACFG =>Basic Settings for Valuation=>Make Cross-Company Code FI-AA Settings per Accounting Principle.

entry.title: Migrating NowShortUrl of QR-Codes from old company to new company in FSM
entry.content:
There are NowShortUrl of QR-codes for equipment generated in old FSM company with SAP B1 as underlying ERP system, while a new FSM company was created from a new Data Base of SAP B1 system as a replacement to the old company. Full data backup & restore was not executed due to concern on synchronization issue of the new company, as the master data and field settings are not identical between the old and new data bases of underlying SAP B1 systems.

We want to reuse the NowShortUrl of QR-codes generated in the old FSM company and migrate them to the new FSM company, but selected data backup & restore for the NowShortUrl is not allowed from presently available Admin functions.

Is there any solution to migrate unpaired NowShortUrl of QR-Codes from old company to new company in FSM?

entry.title: Re: Fiori My Timesheet app default assignment
entry.content:
Hey Juan Carlos,

That's a great question, and I totally get why you're asking. It's a bit of a pain for users with multiple jobs to have to pick their assignment every single time they open an app. It should be smarter, right?

The short answer is that, unfortunately, there isn't a simple switch or setting you can flip to make one job the default. SAP designed it this way on purpose‚Äîkind of like a safety feature. They want to force users to consciously choose the right job so someone doesn't accidentally log their time or check a paystub for the wrong role.

But don't worry, you can definitely solve this and make life easier for your users!

 

The Best Way to Fix It (The Backend Trick) 

 

The most reliable way to handle this is with a bit of code on the backend using a BAdI. Think of a BAdI as an official "hook" that SAP leaves in its code, allowing developers like yours to add custom logic without messing up the original application.

For the My Timesheet app, the specific hook you're looking for is HCM_B_TIMESHEET_MAN_EXT

Here‚Äôs the game plan you can give to your ABAP developer:

  1. Implement the BAdI: They'll need to create an implementation for HCM_B_TIMESHEET_MAN_EXT.

  2. Define Your "Default" Logic: You'll need a way to tell the system which job should be the default. The most flexible way is to create a simple custom Z-table that just maps a user to their preferred PERNR. That way, you can easily change it later without touching the code.

  3. Re-order the List: Inside the BAdI, the developer can write a few lines of code to check your custom table (or whatever logic you decide on) and find the user's default PERNR. Then, they just re-arrange the list of jobs so that the default one is right at the top.

The magic here is that most Fiori apps automatically highlight the first item in the list. So, by putting the right job first, it will already be selected for the user when the pop-up appears. All they have to do is click "OK." It‚Äôs a simple trick that makes a big difference in the user experience!

 

The "Other" Way

There is another option, which involves customizing the app's user interface directly. A Fiori developer could write code to automatically select the default PERNR when the screen loads.

Honestly, I'd recommend avoiding this if you can. It's a bit more fragile because if SAP ever updates the My Timesheet app, your custom UI code could break. The backend BAdI method is much safer and more stable for the long haul.

The Bottom Line

So, to wrap it up:

  • No, there's no standard setting for this.

  • Yes, you can absolutely create a default programmatically.

  • The recommended path is to use the backend BAdI (HCM_B_TIMESHEET_MAN_EXT) to simply put the user's default job at the top of the selection list.

Hope this helps clear things up and gives you a solid path forward!

entry.title: Re: MRP Transfer Requirement Not Defaulting Source Storag...
entry.content:
Hey there,

You are so close! This is a classic SAP puzzle, and it feels like you're just one missing piece away from solving it.

The situation is that MRP is doing its job for Storage Location B. It sees the demand and correctly says, "Hey, we need to create a transfer!" But then it stops and asks, "...a transfer from where?" It doesn't know the source.

What you need to do is give MRP that missing piece of information. You need to create a special rule that essentially tells SAP: "Whenever Storage Location B needs this material, always go get it from Storage Location A."

Here‚Äôs the simple, two-step game plan to get it working.

 

Step 1: Create the "Rule" for the Transfer

 

First, you need to create this "go get it from A" rule. In SAP, this is called a Special Procurement Type.

  1. Hop into transaction OMD9.

  2. Create a new rule for your plant (you can name it something like Z1).

  3. Here are the important settings for your new rule:

    • Procurement Type: Set this to F (for External Procurement).

    • Special Procurement: Set this to U (for Stock Transfer).

    • Issuing storage location: This is the magic field! This is where you tell SAP the source. Put A in here.

Think of this as creating a permanent instruction in the system that says "Z1 means get it from Sloc A."

 

Step 2: Assign the Rule to Your Material

 

Now that you've created the rule, you just need to tell the material in Storage Location B to use it.

  1. Go to the material master using transaction MM02.

  2. Go into the MRP 4 view, but make sure you specify you're looking at the settings for Storage Location B. (You can do this by clicking the "Storage Location MRP" button at the top).

  3. Now, switch to the MRP 2 view (still for Sloc B!).

  4. Find the field Special Procurement Type and put your new rule (Z1) in there.

And That's It!

Now, when you run MRP, the whole process is automatic:

  1. MRP sees demand in Sloc B.

  2. It checks the material master for Sloc B and finds your new rule, Z1.

  3. The rule immediately tells MRP, "Aha! I need to create a stock transfer, and my source is Sloc A."

  4. It then creates the transfer requirement with Sloc A already filled in. No more manual work!

You've basically just connected the dots for MRP so it can complete the whole process on its own.

Hope this helps make it click! Let me know if you have any other questions.

entry.title: Re: Replicating material from a non-SAP system to the S/4...
entry.content:
Hey there,

First off, you're absolutely on the right track. Using that ProductMDMBulkReplicateRequest_In service is exactly how the pros handle this. You've got the right idea, and it's a very common project, so you're not alone in this!

Think of the whole process like setting up an automated, digital mailroom for new materials.

The Goal: A package (your material data) leaves the non-SAP system and arrives at your S/4HANA "mailroom." Instead of a person opening it, an automated robot checks it, approves it, and puts it on the shelf (activates it in the system) instantly.

Here‚Äôs how you build that automated mailroom.

 

1. Set Up the "Digital Loading Dock" (SOA Configuration)

 

Before anything can arrive, you need to open the door. This is a technical step where you go into a transaction called SOAMANAGER and activate the specific "loading dock" (ProductMDMBulkReplicateRequest_In) for your material data. This creates a unique web address (a WSDL) that you'll give to the team handling the non-SAP system, so they know exactly where to send the data packages.

 

2. The "Translator" in the Middle (Middleware)

 

Your non-SAP system speaks one language, and S/4HANA speaks another (a very specific XML format). You need a translator in the middle. This is almost always a middleware tool like SAP CPI (Cloud Platform Integration) or MuleSoft.

This tool's job is to:

  • Pick up the material data from the source system.

  • Map all the fields: "Customer Part Number" from the source becomes "MFRPN" in the XML, for example. This is usually the most time-consuming part of the project.

  • Package it all up perfectly into the required XML format and send it to the "loading dock" address you created in Step 1.

 

3. The "Autopilot" Button (MDG Workflow)

 

This is the fun part and the core of your question! How do we get the Change Request (CR) to create and approve itself?

You do this with a Rule-Based Workflow.

You'll create a special workflow just for these incoming materials. In that workflow, you'll set up a rule that says:

"IF this Change Request was created by our special 'integration user' (the one the middleware uses), THEN skip all the normal human approval steps and send it straight to the final check and activation."

This is the key. It creates a "fast lane" or an "autopilot" for trusted data coming from your other system, while any materials created manually by a person still go through the normal, multi-step approval process.

 

4. Adding Your "Special Instructions" (The BAdIs)

 

You were spot on to ask about BAdIs. These are your secret weapons for adding custom logic. Think of them as special instructions for the "mailroom robot."

The most important BAdI you'll use is USMD_RULE_SERVICE. You can tell it to do things like:

  • Derivations (Auto-filling blanks): "If the material type is 'FERT', then automatically set the purchasing group to '001'." This is for data that the source system doesn't have, but SAP needs.

  • Validations (Quality checks): "If the weight is missing, or the description is too short, stop the process and send an error alert." This ensures bad data never makes it into your system.

 

Your Game Plan Summarized:

 

  1. Map it Out: Get with the business and map every field from the old system to the new S/4HANA material master. This is your blueprint.

  2. Open the Door: Configure the service in SOAMANAGER.

  3. Build the Translator: Get your integration team to build the mapping logic in your middleware.

  4. Set Up the Autopilot: Create the special CR type and the rule-based workflow for the "fast lane" approval.

  5. Write Your Special Rules: Use the BAdI to code any extra derivations and quality checks you need.

It might seem like a lot of moving parts, but it's a very logical flow. You're essentially building a pipeline, and once it's set up, it's incredibly efficient.

You've got this! Hope this helps make the process a bit clearer.

entry.title: Re: VS Code SAP WEB CLIENT Extensibility
entry.content:
Hey there,

You've hit on the number one question that every single developer asks when they move from C# addons to the Web Client. Seriously. It feels like something so simple should be easy to find, but the old way of doing things is just... gone.

The frustrating but simple truth is: there‚Äôs no direct "Before Save" event you can just cancel.

Think of it like this: The old UI API was like working on a car engine directly. You could reach in and physically stop a part from moving. The new Web Client is like using a remote control for that car. You can press the "start engine" button, but you can't magically stop the engine from the remote after the signal has been sent.

So, how do we solve it? We get clever. We do a little "bait and switch" with the Save button.

 

How to Run Checks Before a Save (and Stop It If Needed)

 

The main trick is to take away the user's ability to press the real save button and give them a fake one that's under your control.

Step 1: The "Bait" - Hide SAP's Real Button

First, you tell the system to just hide the normal "Add" or "Update" button so the user can't even click it. You do this right when the screen loads.

TypeScript
 
// Find the real save button (its ID is usually "1")
const realSaveButton = App.getView().getController().getButton("1");

// And just... make it disappear!
if (realSaveButton) {
  realSaveButton.setVisible(false);
}

Step 2: The "Switch" - Add Your Own Button

Now you add your own, identical-looking button right where the old one was. This one is connected to your code.

TypeScript
 
// Create your shiny new button
const mySaveButton = new Button("MyCoolSaveButton");
mySaveButton.setText("Save"); // Or "Add", "Update", etc.

// Put it on the screen and tell it what to do when clicked
App.getView().addButton(mySaveButton);
mySaveButton.onClick(() => this.runMyChecksAndSave());

Step 3: Put Your "Brain" in Your Button's Code

This is where the magic happens. When the user clicks your button, your code runs first.

TypeScript
 
private async runMyChecksAndSave(): Promise<void> {
  // --- 1. RUN YOUR CHECKS ---
  const bpName = await App.getView().getController().getEditText("5").getValue();
  if (bpName.length < 5) {
    // --- 2. IF A CHECK FAILS: Show an error and stop. ---
    // This is how you "cancel" the save. You just don't proceed.
    App.getStatusBar().showError("BP Name is too short!");
    return;
  }

  // --- 3. IF EVERYTHING IS OK: Press the real (hidden) button for the user. ---
  App.getView().getController().pressButton("1");
}

And that's the whole pattern! You let the user think they're pressing the normal button, but they're really pressing yours, giving you a chance to run your checks before deciding whether to proceed with the actual save.

 

How to Run Code After a Successful Save

 

This part is much easier, thankfully!

SAP has given us a "doorbell" that rings every time a document, business partner, or item is successfully saved. You just need to tell your code to listen for that doorbell.

You set this up once in your main scripts/main.ts file.

TypeScript
 
// This doorbell is called "afterSave"
App.events.on.afterSave.add(async (event) => {
  // The 'event' tells you what was just saved
  console.log(`Something was saved! Object Type: ${event.objectType}`);
  console.log(`Its new ID is: ${event.key}`); // This is the DocEntry, CardCode, etc.

  // Now you can do whatever you need to do!
  if (event.objectType === "2") { // If it was a Business Partner...
    App.getStatusBar().showSuccess(`Hooray! BP ${event.key} was saved.`);
  }
});

It's definitely a mental shift from the old way, but once you get this "bait and switch" pattern down for your "before" events, you'll be able to build all the same workflows you used to.

Hope this helps make it a bit clearer! Good luck.

entry.title: Re: Can we suspend interfaces by EventMesh?
SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model: What‚Äôs New as of 2025-10-10?
entry.content:
Hello SAP user community! Continue discovering the latest updates in SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud Universal Model (SAP PaPM Cloud UM) for Q4 2025, with enhancements designed to deliver a smoother and more seamless experience.

You can always stay up to date and explore past releases by following PaPMCloudUMWhatsNew .

Model

Data Screen: Embedded Association Links

Hierarchy levels in the Data screen now feature embedded association links to master data objects, allowing direct access without workflow interruption. 

For more information: Show Data

 

Data screen (Adapt UI): Customize Relation Sub-Grids

This update allows users to customize the display order of relation sub-grids on the Data screen. Using the drag and drop functionality, users can  personalize and organize related data more efficiently. Once reordered and saved via the Adapt UI feature, the new sub-grid arrangement is applied consistently  across all expanded data rows, improving workflow consistency and the overall user experience.

For more information: Adapt UI

 

Data Screen: Group level ‚Äì Select, Delete and Copy

This update introduces group-level selection, deletion, and copying of records within editable tables, enabling bulk actions on entire groups to improve efficiency and reduce repetitive clicks. Users must expand a group before bulk actions become active, ensuring visibility of records to prevent unintended actions, for example, deleting all records under a specific functional area with a single action.

For more information: Application Help for Universal Model > Report Screen: Insert Show Element - Comments Pane and Data Screen:  Comments Pane

 

Model screen / Runtime Model screen: Search feature for Fields, Connections and Partitions

Previously, the Search feature was only available in the Functions tab. With this release, the Search feature has been extended to Fields, Connections, and Partitions tabs on both the Model screen and Show Runtime Model screens.

As you enter a search term, the system instantly filters the rows and displays only the rows whose ID or description contains below the search field

To make navigation easier, the results are categorized into ‚ÄúModeling‚Äù fields and ‚ÄúPalette‚Äù icons, ensuring quick access to the most relevant items.

For more information: Application Help for Universal Model > Model Screen

 

 

Model View / View: Aggregation supports Data-Type Characteristics

Model View and View functions have been enhanced to support aggregation of type ‚ÄúCount‚Äù  on Characteristic field of type ‚ÄúDate‚Äù. The previous restriction requiring the input and output fields of Aggregation of type ‚ÄúCount‚Äù to be of the same type has been removed, providing greater flexibility in data modeling.

This update allows COUNT to be applied to characteristic fields, including dates, with outputs assignable to either numeric Key Figures (such as tiny int, small int, integer, large int, double, or decimal) or Characteristics (String),

While enforcing validation to ensure output fields are of appropriate numeric or string types, thereby improving data modeling flexibility and consistency.

For more information: Application Help for Universal Model > Model View: Aggregation and View: Aggregation

 

Process

Runtime Functions: Total Disk Size of All Table Parts (Bytes) 

A new field called Total Disk Size of All Table Parts (Bytes) is now available in the Display Runtime Functions application  under the Technical Information section, which displays the total disk space used by each runtime function.  This allows users to see how much space their data is using and helps keep track of resource consumption. 

For more information: Application Help for Universal Model > Display Runtime Functions

We hope you enjoy exploring these new features and continue to maximize the value of SAP PaPM Cloud UM.

Stay tuned‚Äîmore enhancements are on the way!

entry.title: Re: An error occurred when converting a purchase requisit...
entry.content:
Hello @ISoma,

this can be standard in S/4HANA Cloud.

What happens when you start ‚ÄúCreate PO‚Äù from Process Purchase Requisitions?

The system marks the PR item as ‚Äúin PO processing.‚Äù If an error occurs and you press Cancel, the UI reverts the change, but depending on your setup, the original PR may end up closed or deleted, or it may be left in a status that cannot be reused. The system (or planning/coverage) promptly generates a new PR to meet the demand. This is why it may seem like the original PR ‚Äúdisappeared‚Äù and was replaced. new one appears.

Useful SAP KBA References:

KBA 3213914 explains why a PR might ‚Äúdisappear‚Äù from the Process Purchase Requisition list, often due to a need for refresh or filters. While this isn't your exact error scenario, it aligns with the ‚Äúdisappeared‚Äù symptom observed in this app. SAP Support Portal-3213914 - Purchase requisition item disappears after changing the item in the Process Purchase Requisition app

KBA 3317667 addresses conversion errors associated with ‚ÄúPurchase Requisition Handover to Purchasing Required‚Äù in SSCUI 102373. The typical resolution is to create a new PR, which aligns with the behaviour observed after cancellation.  SAP Support Portal-3213914 - Purchase requisition item disappears after changing the item in the Process Purchase Requisition app

KBA 3662338 ‚Äì status handling after converting PR to PO and then reversing; shows PR status doesn‚Äôt always revert, which is why the system may not reuse the same PR item. SAP Support Portal-3662338 - Purchase Requisition remains in status "PO Created" after referenced PO item is deleted (S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)

What you should check

In Define MRP Groups (SSCUI 102373), check if Handover to Purchasing Required is enabled. If it is, either keep it and accept the ‚Äúnew PR‚Äù behaviour on failures, or disable it if your process requires reuse. SAP Support Portal-3317667 - Error occurs when converting purchase requisition to purchase order

Refresh or clear filters in the app to ensure the original PR isn‚Äôt simply hidden (per KBA 3213914).SAP Support Portal-3213914 - Purchase requisition item disappears after changing the item in the Process Purchase Requisition app.

Let me know if it helps

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series: From Stress to Strength - Running as My Lifelong Hobby
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I want to continue this blog series about SAP Community Hobbies.

It's amazing how you can meet people and discover new things in the community just through chatting and blogging with other members.

I want to say thank you to @act45 . I also remember him perfectly. In a world of work and technology, his presentation at the SAP Inside Track Copenhagen about mindfulness opened the doors to my mind to something that‚Äôs not just about hard work and software but also introspection and positive energy, which not many people share in their lives.

Another community member shifted her focus to something more important than just work, @sveabecker , and I would love for her to share her new path and dedication.

How I Started Running

As for me, I started running when I was young, in college. And why? Because of the stress from exams. Like Achim, I found a way to get rid of all my bad thoughts.

My first running shoes

 

I wasn‚Äôt working at the time, and I needed something inexpensive that I could do before a big exam.
Running was perfect.
Nothing competitive, just long-distance running. When I started, I didn‚Äôt even measure the distance. I used a stopwatch, and I‚Äôd stop after 20 or 30 minutes to go back home. Each time, I tried to go further than before.

What Running Means to Me Today

Years later, running has become more than just a way to handle stress. it‚Äôs part of my lifestyle.
When I travel for work or conferences, I always pack two pairs of shoes: one for work, and one for running. üòÅ
Exploring a new city through running gives me a completely different perspective compared to seeing it by car or train.

A fun race in NYC (Central Park) with my wife

 

 

And where I meet new friends, I joined running clubs in my new city in the U.S. They help me not only improve my pace but also meet new people. Running is no longer just a solitary activity for me; it‚Äôs about community and friendship, too.
I cannot wait to see my friends on Saturday to run together! 

Challenges and Lessons Learned (my angel wife)

Like many runners, I‚Äôve had my share of injuries. I struggled with knee pain, and it almost made me quit. Thanks to my wife, who encouraged me to see a physiotherapist, I learned the most important lesson: rest is as important as training.

Me running with my team

 

This applies not only to running but also to life and work. You can‚Äôt push endlessly without breaks. To achieve goals, balance and recovery are essential. Suggestion from my PT is also to do a lot of stretching that I include on a daily basis, and yoga has become a perfect sport to match. 

My Biggest Achievements

- My first half-marathon, at the time, it felt like a mountain, but today it reminds me how far I‚Äôve come.
- Running my own ‚Äúultra marathon‚Äù around the island of Manhattan, covering 57 km in one day. It wasn‚Äôt an official race, but it gave me immense joy and confidence.

Picture of my first solo marathon

 

 

Connecting Running with SAP Life

Running clears my mind after intense projects and helps me face the next challenge with more energy.

Just like in running, in SAP projects you need endurance, discipline, and trust that every small step will bring you closer to the finish line.

FUN FACT: In all the pictures you see with a cap. That is the SAP Community cap üòÑ I still running with it all the time üôÇ

Passing the Baton

I met @Sandra_Solis  at the last TechEd in the US. Sandra paints beautiful places she visits, and for me, running is also a way to travel and explore. While I run through streets and landscapes, Sandra captures them on canvas. Both of us, in our own way, transform experiences into something lasting.

If you want to connect on Strava and you are a runner, please feel free to add me here:
https://www.strava.com/athletes/26298351
And if you pass by NYC, don't hesitate to ask me to run üòÑ I will always accept.

 


Start with walking and then running: Have any of you recently run a race? And how do you train for running?

entry.title: Streamlining User Management in SAP Ariba Category Management with SAP Cloud Identity Services
entry.content:
This blog post highlights an important update in user management within SAP Ariba Category Management, released in May 2025. The new, centralized approach minimizes manual intervention and boosts security, simplifying processes and enhancing efficiency. For customers with SAP Ariba Category Management tenants provisioned after May 16, 2025, no action is required. These tenants automatically follow the user group-based model.  SAP Ariba Category Management tenants provisioned before May 16, 2025 require manual adjustments. 

This post outlines the necessary steps to transition from role-based assignments to a user group-based model and guides you through the transition process.

 

What‚Äôs Changed

With the May 2025 release we provided a significant improvement in the way user management is handled within SAP Ariba Category Management. You can now assign predefined, category management-specific user groups directly from the Identity Authentication service in SAP Cloud Identity Services to SAP Ariba Category Management users (Figure 1).

Figure 1: User groups for SAP Ariba Category Management

In the past, user data had to be replicated from the Identity Authentication service tenant to SAP Ariba Category Management. This involved scheduling regular synchronization jobs and assigning roles through separate user interfaces. Now, users who need access to SAP Ariba Category Management are assigned predefined user groups directly within the Identity Authentication service tenant in SAP Cloud Identity Services. 

Note: Setting up a replication job is still required for integration with the embedded SAP Analytics Cloud and the intelligent opportunity analyzer. For more information, see Replicating Users from Identity Authentication Service to SAP Analytics Cloud.

 

Key Benefits

  • You can assign user groups directly within SAP Cloud Identity Services without using the SAP BTP cockpit's application configuration UI. This ensures all user management activities are centralized in one place.
  • Previously, syncing user data required a replication job between Identity Authentication and SAP Ariba Category Management. With this update, user replication for SAP Ariba Category Management is no longer needed, streamlining the process further.

Note: Setting up a replication job is still required for integration with the embedded SAP Analytics Cloud and the intelligent opportunity analyzer. For more information, see Replicating Users from Identity Authentication Service to SAP Analytics Cloud.

 

Steps for Transitioning Tenants Provisioned before May 16, 2025

If you provisioned SAP Ariba Category Management before the May 2025 release, you need to make some manual adjustments to transition to the new model. The concrete steps you need to follow depend on whether your SAP Ariba Category Management tenants were provisioned in an SAP-managed SAP BTP account, following the simplified provisioning approach via SAP for Me, or whether your tenants were manually provisioned in a customer-managed SAP BTP account.

 

SAP-Managed Setup (Simplified Provisioning)

These steps are relevant for tenants provisioned after August 16, 2024 and before May 16, 2025.

Step 1: Assign the predefined category management-specific user groups to SAP Ariba Category Management users in SAP Cloud Identity Services (Figure 2).

Figure 2: Assigning user groups to users in SAP Cloud Identity Services

For more information, see the configuration guide at Assigning Category Management User Groups to Users on SAP Cloud Identity Services.

Step 2: In the SAP BTP cockpit, remove individual users assigned directly to role collections (Figure 3).

Figure 3: Removing role collections from users in SAP BTP Cockpit

For more information, see the configuration guide at Delete Users from Role Collections.

Step 3: Delete the target system created for SAP Ariba Category Management, or alternatively, remove the SAP Ariba Category Management target system from the source system on the SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant.

Figure 4: Deleting the target system from SAP Cloud Identity Services

For more information, see configuration guide at Delete Target System.

 

Customer-Managed Setup (Manual Provisioning)

These steps are relevant for tenants provisioned before August 16, 2024.

Step 1: Create category management-specific user groups in SAP Cloud Identity Services (Figure 5), using the user group names and display names described in the configuration guide. For more information, see Creating User Groups for Category Management Users.

Figure 5: Creating user groups for SAP Ariba Category Management

Step 2: Assign the predefined category management-specific user groups to SAP Ariba Category Management users in SAP Cloud Identity Services (Figure 2). For more information, see Assigning Category Management User Groups to Users on SAP Cloud Identity Services.

Step 3: Map the created user groups to the corresponding role collections in the SAP Ariba Category Management subaccount on SAP BTP (Figure 6).

Figure 6: Mapping role collections to user groups

For more information, see Mapping User Groups to Role Collections.

Step 4: Remove individual users assigned directly to role collections in the SAP BTP cockpit (Figure 3). For more information, see Delete Users from Role Collections.

Step 5: Delete the target system created for SAP Ariba Category Management, or alternatively, remove the SAP Ariba Category Management target system from the source system on the SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant (Figure 4). For  more information, see Delete Target System.

 

Conclusion

Transitioning to a user group-based access model in SAP Ariba Category Management is pivotal to a more streamlined, secure, and efficient user management process. For customers with existing tenants, it's crucial to migrate to the new process, while those with new tenants will see immediate benefits from automatic configurations.

For detailed steps and further guidance, explore the following resources in the configuration guide for SAP Ariba Category Management on SAP Help Portal:

  • User Management
  • Assigning Category Management User Groups to Users on SAP Cloud Identity Services
  • Migration of SAP Ariba Category Management Tenants to User Group-Based Access

entry.title: Re: Data validation on extension version
entry.content:
Hi Arnold,

I recommend creating a second validation method by duplicating the one used in the standard version. In this new method, remove any validation rules that are incompatible with the Group Currency Extension version.

Next, open the Assign Validation Method app. First, select the standardized validation task. Then, at the top of the screen, choose your Group Currency Extension version in which you want to change the assigned method. Finally, assign the newly created validation method to that version.

I hope this approach resolves the issue.

Best regards,
Luca

You're on the right track by being careful about where you get your SAP C_THR88_2505 practice materials. Many sites advertise ‚Äúreal exam dumps,‚Äù but most of them are outdated or unreliable. In some cases, they can even mislead you with incorrect questions or violate SAP‚Äôs testing policies.

Moreover, That said, I‚Äôve seen a lot of discussions in SAP forums and study communities about Pass4Future. entry.title: Re: How to access the SAP HANA Cloud database behind a BT...
entry.content:
1) The access to the underlying SAP HANA Cloud instance is always ABAP-managed. There is no access possible bypassing the ABAP stack. This approach has two important advantages: Uniform Identity and Access Management to the the data and uniform lifecycle management for all artefacts of a solution. 

To access HANA artefacts natively, ABAP offers "ABAP-managed database procedures (AMDP)", see https://help.sap.com/docs/abap-cloud/abap-data-models/abap-data-models?version=sap_btp

2) For MT SaaS scenarios, SAP BTP ABAP Environment is making use of the CLIENT field to separate different tenant (not different HDI containers). Please refer to https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-btp-abap-environment/abap-environment/multitenancy-in-abap-environment

entry.title: 2H 2025 - Release highlights of SuccessFactors Succession Management
entry.content:
Hi Community,

The 2H 2025 release is here!

A new set of enhancements has been released in the 2H 2025 release that has been eagerly awaited. The SAP SuccessFactors 2H 2025 Release includes some key features and enhancements, so let's take a closer look!

1- Filter Position Tile View with Foundation Objects:

Users can now add Foundation Objects as filters to narrow down the positions displayed in the Position Tile view.

If you've configured a setting to include Foundation Objects in filters and have added Foundation Object fields as searchable fields to the Position object, those Foundation Objects will show up as available filters in the Position Tile view.

Regardless of which fields of a Foundation Object you make searchable, the Position Tile View displays the Foundation Object itself as a filter. For example, whether you add location.name or location.externalCode, users see the Location filter. If you add both location.name and location.externalCode, only one Location filter is displayed.

Enablement: Customer configured

Configuration Requirements:

  • The setting Include Generic Objects and Foundation Objects in filters in the Position Tile view is selected in Admin Center >Succession Settings.
  • This setting was previously used to include Generic Objects only and is now expanded to cover Foundation Objects as well. If you've already enabled this setting, Foundation Object-type filters are automatically available in the Position Tile view.

 

Access Inactive Employees in Talent Pools Based on Target Population:

Users can now view and manage inactive talent pool nominees who are in the target population of their permissions.

The existing admin setting Apply target population to talent pool nominations permissions only allows users to access active employees in their target population. To cover inactive employees, we introduced a new setting called Include inactive users in target population of talent pool nominations permissions as a child setting under the existing one. When the existing setting is enabled, you can further enable the new setting so that users can access talent pool nominations for both active and inactive employees in their target population.

Specifically, when you enable the new setting, inactive employees in the target population appear in the following places:

  • Talent pools
  • Talent pool sections on the position card
  • The Talent Pool Nominations section on the talent card
  • The Talent Pool Nominations card in the latest People Profile, or the Current Nominations block in the legacy People Profile
  • Talent search results for talent pools

This enhancement makes it possible to show inactive employees in talent pools while applying target population.

Enablement: Customer configured

Configuration Requirements:

  • You've selected the Include inactive users in target population of talent pool nominations permissions option under Admin Center>Nominations Setup

Role-Based Permission Prerequisites:

  • You have the Administrator Permissions>Manage Succession>Succession Management permission.

3- AI-Assisted Successor Recommendation:

Leveraging generative AI capabilities, succession planners can view a reference list of potential successors who are recommended based on their skills, competencies, and work experience.

When you've enabled the Suggested Successors feature, you can further enable the AI-Assisted Successor Recommendation feature and configure the criteria and weights used in the recommendation. The default configuration assigns weights of 50% to "skills and competencies" and 50% to "work experience".

If you choose to include both "skills and competencies" and "work experience", generative AI uses the following data to recommend successors:

  • Position-related job families, job roles, and job profiles in Job Profile Builder
  • Skills and competencies in the Growth Portfolio
  • Job information and external work experience in People Profile

The AI-generated content is stored on the position card for three days, after which it expires and becomes invisible. Users can regenerate the content at any time.

 

Compared with the Suggested Successors feature, the new feature incorporates more role-related data sources in generating recommendations, providing more relevant results to help improve the effectiveness of succession planning.

Configuration Requirements:

  • You're using the MDF or legacy position-based nomination method.
  • You've migrated to Talent Intelligence Hub and enabled the Growth Portfolio.
  • You've purchased the AI units license. For more information about AI units license, please contact your Account Executive.
  • You've consented to the AI Usage Acknowledgment Statement.
  • You've enabled the Suggested Successors feature.
  • You've contacted Technical Support to activate the AI-Assisted Successor Recommendation feature in your system.
  • You've selected Assisted Successor Recommendation in the AI Services Administration admin tool.
  • (Optional) You've configured the criteria and weights for AI-Assisted Successor Recommendation in the Nominations Setup admin tool.

Role-Based Permission Prerequisites:

  • To enable this feature, you must have the Administrator Permissions>Manage AI Capabilities>AI Services Administration permission.
  • To configure this feature, you must have the Administrator Permissions>Manage Succession>Succession Management permission.
  • User Permissions>AI Access>Assisted Successor Recommendation
  • User Permissions>Career Development Planning>Recommended Successors permission. Only people included in the target population can be recommended.

4- Enhanced Suggested Successors Feature:

The Suggested Successors feature now supports using the skills and competency proficiency levels from Growth Portfolio. Additionally, users can now view a role readiness explanation for each suggested successor.

If you've migrated to Talent Intelligence Hub and enabled Growth Portfolio, the Suggested Successors feature uses skill and competency ratings from Growth Portfolio to calculate role readiness, aligning with the calculation method in Career Worksheet.

When users hover over the role readiness of a suggested successor, they can select the information icon to view the explanation in a popover dialog. This dialog categorizes all attributes required by the position's role into two groups‚Äîmatched and unmatched‚Äîbased on whether the suggested successor's current ratings meet the expected ratings of these attributes.

Enablement: Automatically on

Configuration Requirements:

  • You've enabled the Suggested Successors feature.

5- Separate Permission Control for Viewing Nomination History:

You can now use role-based permissions to control whether users who can nominate successors or view talent pool nominees are allowed to access the history of successor or talent pool nominations.

       Enablement: Automatically On

6- Show Person-Based Nominations on Talent Card and People Profile:

The Succession talent card and both the legacy and latest People Profile now show an employee's nominations from all their employments, including nominations to positions (or incumbents) and talent pool nominations.

When you've selected the admin setting Show person-based nominations for employees with global assignments or concurrent employments, users with proper permissions can view all nomination records of an employee.

Nominations on Succession Talent Card

 

Nominations on People Profile

Configuration Requirements:

  • Global Assignment or Concurrent Employment is enabled.
  • The setting Show person-based nominations for employees with global assignments or concurrent employments is selected in Admin Center>Nominations Setup.

Role-Based Permission Prerequisites:

  • To enable this feature, you must have the Administrator Permissions>Manage Succession>Succession Management permission.
  • To configure this feature, you must have the User Permissions>Succession Planner>Succession Planning permission.
  • To view a person's talent pool nominations, users must have the following permissions:

                User Permissions>Miscellaneous Permissions>Talent Pool>View Current

                User Permissions>Succession Planner>View Talent Pool Nomination

For a detailed release summary, check out the ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs New Viewer‚Äù for a list of enhancements across the application.

entry.title: Re: Intercompany individual purchase order scenario
entry.content:
To ensure availability check during STO delivery creation looks into unrestricted inventory, not sales order stock ‚Äî especially for MTS scenarios, follow the below steps

Go to OMB1, Create a rule that prioritizes unrestricted stock over other stock types (e.g., blocked, sales order stock). Example sequence: Unrestricted ‚Üí Blocked ‚Üí Sales Order Stock. Assign Stock Determination Group in MRP-2 view of material master. This links the material to the rule defined in OMB1. Optionally, you can also assign the stock determination rule to Specif movement types and Specific users. This helps enforce stock selection during delivery or goods issue. Go to OVZ9, ensure the checking rule used for STO delivery (typically 'B') includes Unrestricted stock and Excludes sales order stock if not needed. This controls what stock types are considered during delivery creation.

If possible, do not link the STO to a sales order in MTS scenarios. Linking to a sales order forces the system to check sales order stock, which is reserved and not usable for general delivery

Now with the above settings, test with a STO creation without sale order linkage, and create delivery. Confirm that system checks unrestricted stock and allows delivery

entry.title: Re: Implementing custom compensation statements
entry.content:
Hi @swagatikapanda 

There are many approaches you can apply to fix it. Here is one which you can try :-

  1. After declaring decimal format try declaring number format for Slovakia, and US

 <xsl:template match="/">
        <xsl:variable name="locale" select="'sk-SK'"/> <!-- Change to 'en-US' for US formatting -->

  •  Instead of directly writing  xsl: value of select = " '###, ###' " rewrite it as 

  <xsl:choose>
            <xsl:when test="$locale = 'sk-SK'">
                <xsl:value-of select="format-number($customfield, '#,##0.00', 'sk-SK')"/>
            </xsl:when>
            <xsl:when test="$locale = 'en-US'">
                <xsl:value-of select="format-number($customfield, '#,##0.00', 'en-US')"/>
            </xsl:when>
            <xsl:otherwise>
                <xsl:text>Unsupported locale</xsl:text>
            </xsl:otherwise>
        </xsl:choose>

Lastly, check your number formats whichever you are having in your Plan configuration.

Kind Regards, 

Archisha
